review_title: Good place to work but not the highest paid

pros: You meet a lot of conference goers and make connections. You gain customer service skills that translate to any position anywhere in the future. You get the experience of thinking on your feet. Guest Services work as a team. They have to to succeed so gaining those team skills are valuable.
cons: The compensation is low. There can be tense situations with guests if they are frustrated, but in my experience you are trained for those moments and your leaders will support you.

pros: Excellent professors who really care about their students, high faculty to student ratio.

pros: Supportive and community oriented employer. I felt like I was part of the team, even though I was in an administrative, not an academic position. Benefits were good.
cons: Sometimes the pay seemed under the industry standard, but for central PA, it was fine.

pros: Community values are shown throughout your work. The people are great and students are friendly
cons: As a student worker, you don't have a lot of room to be creative and make big decisions.

pros: Beautiful campus with excellent extra-curricular activities. Students who fit into the religious and cultural beliefs of the organization will find others like them.
cons: A narrow vision of diversity. This is a white evangelical Christian organization. The beliefs and expectations that accompany this cultural group are prevalent. If you are female, homosexual, interested in research and publishing be careful here. The warm welcome is not extended to everyone. Read the community covenant carefully.

pros: Understanding of student's schedules, welcoming environment
cons: I have no cons for Messiah

review_title: Blurred lines between personal and professional lives
pros: Great benefits, pretty campus, very safe area, students are great
cons:
There is an unhealthy expectation of being unrealistically positive all the time. There are some very nice people, but there is also a pervasive culture of disingenuousness that can be hard to stomach.
Additionally, the oft-repeated phrase that "working at Messiah is a ministry" gives an excuse to pile on more work without giving promotions or raises that would compensate for the amount of time put into said work (but you should still be happy, because after all, it's a ministry!).

Generally speaking, there are some other significant cons that are not necessarily  unique to Messiah, but the fact that it is a Christian institution means that it's a greater disappointment when situations are handled poorly. 

In the midst of budget cuts, veteran employees are being let go to make way for rookies who are hired at a lower salary. Loyalty from Messiah to its employees is currently plummeting.

If you want to advance here, be prepared to kiss up to your directors.

Overall it's an average place. I wouldn't necessarily give it a strong recommendation, but if you're looking for a job it's worth exploring.  Your experience will vary from department to department.

review_title: Student Employment within a Christian College
pros: I consider the positions I worked as a student employee to be beneficial, educational and a definite asset to my professional growth. Though considerably different, the people I worked with were great, knowledgeable, and very helpful. There was little pressure so long as you performed what you were hired to do but there was always opportunity to push beyond the confines of what you were hired to do. I always found someone willing to share their knowledge as free education to better myself.
cons: Even within the confines of a Christian College, I encountered work place politics on campus from time to time but I can't say it was anywhere near to other places I've worked for in the past.

review_title: My experience working at Messiah has been great!
job_title: Student Program Manager in Mechanicsburg, PA
pros: Messiah really does have a welcoming community where different viewpoints and strategies are encouraged. The environment produces strong leaders with heart and commitment to their jobs.
cons: Sometimes, the Christian aspect can be difficult to deal with, even though I myself am a Christian. It's not always easy to navigate certain situations with co-workers, especially the more opinionated ones. However, they are so understanding and willing to help out if you have a personal/family issue that needs urgent attention.

review_title: Working Over The Summer at Messiah
pros: Working at Messiah was a great experience. I bonded very well with my teammates and supervisors, and everyone was focused on serving well and having fun.
cons: Do not choose if you are exhausted by crowds or multitasking. Not many positions open for introverted individuals or people who prefer working alone. Pay is minimum wage.

review_title: Great place, great people, great mission, mediocre salary
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Hampden Township, PA
pros: I believe strongly in the mission of the institution, and the people there are awesome. Great atmosphere, beautiful campus. Great paid time off and benefits too!
cons: Money. The salary is really bad. There's also very high turnover, mostly because they're always hiring super young people who "find themselves" and then leave after 18 months.

job_title: Computer Support Technician in Mechanicsburg, PA
pros: -good training. Environment in nice in general. In general.
cons: -Not for a long standing tho. Despite is a Christian college, not everybody is Christian and that can leads to some misunderstandings.
